title: Bottom Panel visibility

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
I'm writing an extension and I'm struggling with toggling the bottom panel though the API.

I'm able to `hide()` or `show()` a terminal that leads to open and close the panel, but there is no `toggle()` feature or a way to test terminal or panel visibility to call either `hide` or `show`.

I saw that the Panel object has a `visible` member, but I can't find a way to access the panel instance through the API.

title: [json] $ref breaks validation of additionalItems

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.31.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.14.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a JSON-Schema where a `$ref` is used inside `additionalItems`
```json
{
  "type": "array",
  "items": [
    {
      "type": "string"
    }
  ],
  "additionalItems": {
    "$ref": "#/definitions/Number"
  },
  "definitions": {
    "Number": {
      "type": "integer"
    }
  }
}
```
2. Create a JSON file where the additional items in the array do not conform to the schema
```json
[
  "A string",
  "Definitely not an integer"
]
```
3. Set VSCode up to validate the JSON file against the schema

Expected result:

Squiggly lines below the second item in the array.

Actual result:

JSON file passes validation

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

Please enable Hover: sticky by default on the color picker pop up or let us click on the small colored square for a color selector window pop-up. This is a must, because by default, Hover: sticky makes for some annoying tooltips and must be disabled. Thank you, I really hope you consider this. title: Ability to re use a view across view containers

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

title: Support firing onDidCloseTextDocument events immediately for testing
body:
I know the behaviour of calling `onDidCloseTextDocument` "up to 3 mins later" is by-design, but it seems to make close handlers completely untestable (for example, ensuring that the language server is notified when this happens). It also means that these close events can fire during subsequent tests which may affect their results.

Is it possible to have *some* ability to force them to fire (and wait until they have) in a test? It's not practical to have up to a 3 minute delay at the end of every test. It seems like there should be some ability to handle this.

title: Support running multiple tests suites at the same time
body:
Integration tests for extensions can be kinda slow so it'd be great if we could spawn separate instances of Code to run different tests at the same time on CI services. Currently this happens:

> Running extension tests from the command line is currently only supported if no other instance of Code is running.

The word **currently** in that message suggests that this may be a temporary limitation, though I couldn't find an existing issue about relaxing that restriction.

Is it possible?

title: MarkdownString.appendText doesn't handle visually significant whitespace
body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.30.2 (61122f88f0bf01e2ac16bdb9e1bc4571755f5bd8, 2019-01-07T22:54:13.295Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17763

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Respond to an LSP hover with a MarkupContent of kind `plaintext` with visually significant whitespace.
2. See hover formatted improperly in the editor.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: N/A

The Python extension uses `vscode-languageclient` to communicate with a language server over LSP. The LSP has support for `plaintext` as a markup kind in many calls, for example, hover. `vscode-languageclient` converts `MarkupContent` of kind `plaintext` to VS Code's `MarkdownString` by using `appendText` to append the text as is:

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/blob/5a198a0982e3d8f538a2f30fa87eb4ca27f1728d/client/src/protocolConverter.ts#L294-L297

Which is implemented as:

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/527b6628e6bdcb046a31bbcb0cd17c3702c4ee8a/src/vs/base/common/htmlContent.ts#L24-L28

However, escaping these special characters isn't enough to convert plaintext to something that's rendered properly in markdown. For example, the following Python code:

```python
def func(param1=True, param2='default val'):
    '''Description of func with docstring groups style.

    Params:
        param1 - descr of param1 that has True for default value.
        param2 - descr of param2

    Returns:
        some value

    Raises:
        keyError: raises key exception
        TypeError: raises type exception

    '''
    pass
```

Could produce, on hover of `func`, the following LSP response:

```json
Result: {
    "contents": {
        "kind": "plaintext",
        "value": "func(param1=True, param2='default val')\n\nDescription of func with docstring groups style.\n\n    Params:\n        param1 - descr of param1 that has True for default value.\n        param2 - descr of param2\n\n    Returns:\n        some value\n\n    Raises:\n        keyError: raises key exception\n        TypeError: raises type exception\n\n    "
    },
    "range": {
        "start": {
            "line": 0,
            "character": 4
        },
        "end": {
            "line": 0,
            "character": 8
        }
    }
}
```

The signature is on the first line, followed by the docstring unmodified. However, the hover actually appears as:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5341706/51714204-64c53e80-1fe9-11e9-8cc2-5b10625d3efe.png)

Because in markdown a four space indent means a code block, producing a dual effect of text being rendered as code and exposing the markdown escaping done previously.

A more extreme example:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5341706/51715686-a60c1d00-1fee-11e9-97c3-ec5266134e6e.png)

For our purposes, it may be "enough" for the leading whitespace to be replaced with ` `, but that may not fully handle every case.

title: vscode.workspace.asRelativePath should support to return a real path
body:
If a workspace folder has a name defined in its *.code-workspace file,
`vscode.workspace.asRelativePath` will return paths that start with this name and which cannot be found in the filesystem.

I propose to add a second boolean argument to `asRelativePath` to force it to return the real relative path. Without that it is very difficult to determine the real relative path for a given url.

/cc @bpasero

title: Allow to navigate to symbols globally within a file
body:
I would like to navigate through files more like sublime, for example:

let's suppose I have a file called "_SomeController.php_" and inside this file, I have a method called "_someMethod_". Even if I have no opened file in the editor I can open the file navigator with "_ctrl+p_" command and type "_somecon@someme_" and the navigator can find the file and the method and open the file with the cursor selecting the name of the desired method.

![screenshot from 2019-02-18 10-06-28](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12631274/52953002-00d23380-3365-11e9-8a39-31fe87ca3e69.png)
(Image from sublime)


Currently, if I do this same process in _vscode_, the file navigator does find the selected file if I had typed "_somecon_", but when I try to insert the symbol "_someme_" it fails to find the file and the method. Even if I type the whole filename and the symbol (eg: "_SomeController.php@someMethod_") the editor cant find the file/method.

![screenshot from 2019-02-18 10-08-07](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12631274/52953082-35de8600-3365-11e9-9bfe-598aaeea1aa5.png)
(image from vscode)

title: Support more CSS for decorations before/after properties: border-radius, padding, border-width
body: I'd like to be able to make decorations that use `before`/`after` to insert little badges, but they look bad without rounded corners or padding: `borderRadius` and `borderWidth` are both available on the decoration itself, but not on the `after` content. Padding would be better, though just having radius/width for borders would probably allow me to do the job by just using left/right borders.

title: Trailing whitespace (but not leading) is trimmed from decorations after:contentText
body: Given a decoration with leading/trailing whitespace in the `contextText` for the `after` property: The trailing space is trimmed, but the leading space is not which feels a little inconsistent: (Sure, I'd rather not use spaces, but it seems there's no way to set padding, or borders only on the sides, and text looks terrible with a BG and no padding :-))

body:

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.31.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a folder with VS Code. The folder should contain the file you want to rename, say it's `a.txt`.
2. Open `a.txt` with another application (I gave it as input to a program running with Visual Studio).
3. While the program is running, try to rename the file in VS Code source tree.

Result: The file is not renamed (as it's used by another application) but there's no way to know why it wasn't renamed.
Expected result: The file is not renamed and a message box appears (or in some other way) to inform that the file cannot be renamed as it is being used by another application.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Place editor groups side-by-side with The Panel
body:
I want to be able to split the window more freely. Specifically when using a small screen it gets hard to follow the output of some extension or task, or something in the terminal while editing a file and having  another file split open for reference. Here's what that can look like on a small screen:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30010/52904508-bbf7b100-322d-11e9-9d91-1f127402e0a2.png)

Moving the panel to the right does not really help:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30010/52911600-29472880-32a6-11e9-891a-dacc636caaa6.png)

If I could move an editor group down side by side with the panel (or below or under it when it is placed to the right) this would save me a lot of moving around between tabs and groups.

This gets extra important with some extensions that contribute WebViews with much of their UI. They are sometimes more panel-like than editor-like.

With this feature added screen real estate could be used like so:

![bitmap](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30010/52904570-08db8780-322e-11e9-96da-b3e0cffacce0.png)

Or with the panel to the right:

![bitmap](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30010/52904578-1bee5780-322e-11e9-8ecb-11f6c21c6d5f.png)

I think that it could be made general so that also the explorer pane could participate in this sharing.

Let me know if my suggestion is not clear enough, and I'll try to improve on it.

title: "Put away" feature for intentional, selective hot exit
body:
I'm suggesting a "put away" feature to manually keep a list of previously opened workspaces.

Instead of closing a folder/workspace, you could "put away" the workspace. This closes the workspace in the "hot exit" way and puts it on a list of "put away workspaces" (in the File menu or via a command). When you choose the workspace from this list, it opens (potentially in a new window) and is removed from the list. This allows intentional use of hot exit while minimizing the risk of changes being lost.

## Rationale

I commonly use VS Code for a number of different projects that I work on when I find the time, and hot exit is a good way to leave things where they are and get back to them later. Right now, I have to use multiple windows to get hot exit for all projects. (Keeping multiple windows open increases the resource load dramatically, especially with .NET Core projects, which each kick off OmniSharp for the background windows.) According to [a comment on issue #15467](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/15467#issuecomment-272853284), Close Folder should work to hot exit only one window, but it doesn't work for me, maybe because the issue pre-dates multiple-folder workspaces, or maybe because it's been changed since - hot exit is supposed to "just work", and feels like magic when it does and frustration when it doesn't.

Allowing intentional, selective hot exit would let me retain the changes for later, but might make it easier to forget about changes, and because folders and files are easily opened day-to-day in VS Code, the activity in the recent list can scroll them off the bottom. Having a "Put away" command to hot exit a workspace, combined with putting the workspace on a manually kept list from which it may be later chosen surfaces intentional, selective hot exit while providing a reasonable safety net.

## Counterarguments (or: Hot exit considered harmful)

Instead of asking hot exit to save me, in an ideal world, I should just keep my stuff more organized, and/or use git and branching. However, that's an argument against hot exit overall. In a world where hot exit *does* exist, I should be able to use it in an intentional way.

title: File System Providers vs Debug

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body: Issue Type: Bug When a debug session is started from a text editor bound to a file system provider like `vscode-sshfs`, the debugger is initialized with `DebugProtocol.InitializeRequestArguments.pathFormat` set to `path` (and vscode-debugadapter also does not support any other `pathFormat`). Perhaps as a consequence, e.g. `DebugProtocol.SetBreakpointsArguments` then also contain only the path component of the actual address. Since URI support is present in other APIs, say, ```ts let uri = vscode.Uri.parse('ssh://example.org/example/example.pl'); vscode.workspace.openTextDocument(uri).then( doc => vscode.window.showTextDocument(doc) ); ``` It would be nice if debugging features also had support for them, especially before users come to rely on the current broken behaviour. The use case here is simplified remote debugging, I would like to connect a remote workspace folder using a file system provider like `vscode-sshfs` and then start a remote debug session without the need to configure elaborate path mappings and without the need to somehow synchronize local sources and remotely deployed code. VS Code version: Code 1.31.0 (7c66f58312b48ed8ca4e387ebd9ffe9605332caa, 2019-02-06T08:51:24.856Z) OS version: Linux x64 4.15.0-45-generic

title: Behavior between Find in Selection in Find Widget and Alt + L is not consistent
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.31.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Select a line of text and click on the `Find in Selection` in the Find Widget.
2. Click on the `Find in Selection` again. It doesn't remove the `Find in Selection` search scope.

Try steps again with `Alt + l`.

When you use `Alt + l` on step 2 it removes the `Find in Selection`.

It would help if the button mirrored how `Alt + l` works.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No
